nodes.name: suboptimal utility maximization in embedded AI systems
nodes.description: AI systems whose decision procedures do not account for their physical embedding can systematically obtain lower utility than theoretically achievable, especially in environments containing predictors or logical copies of the agent.
nodes.node_rationale: Section 4 Discussion emphasises that neither classical CDT nor EDT consistently ‘win’, creating a top-level safety risk.

nodes.name: dualistic decision-making assumption mismatch in embedded context
nodes.description: Traditional Savage decision theory treats the agent as separate from the environment; when the agent is physically embedded this assumption breaks and action probabilities depend on hidden environmental state.
nodes.node_rationale: Introduced in Section 1 Introduction as the root cause of decision errors.

nodes.name: actions as simultaneous evidence and causal influence in physicalistic model
nodes.description: In a physicalistic model an agent’s chosen action both changes the world and updates the agent’s belief about hidden state, because copies or predictors of the agent correlate action with environment.
nodes.node_rationale: Key insight (Sections 1–2) motivating new decision frameworks.

nodes.name: sequential decision-theoretic extensions for embedded agents
nodes.description: Design principle to generalise causal and evidential decision theories to sequential settings, producing SAEDT, SPEDT and SCDT that compute value functions over future interaction cycles.
nodes.node_rationale: Section 3 introduces these as the primary solution approach.

nodes.name: action-evidential value function in sequential decision-making
nodes.description: Computes expected utility by conditioning only on the immediate next action when updating beliefs about hidden state (SAEDT, Eq. ( SAEDT )).
nodes.node_rationale: Detailed in Section 3.3 as one concrete algorithm.

nodes.name: policy-evidential value function in sequential decision-making
nodes.description: Computes expected utility by conditioning on the entire future policy from current time until lifetime end, giving stronger evidential updates (SPEDT, Eq. ( SPEDT )).

nodes.name: causal value function in sequential decision-making
nodes.description: Uses Pearl’s do-operator to intervene on the next action while keeping beliefs about hidden state unchanged (SCDT, Eq. ( SCDT )).
nodes.node_rationale: Section 3.4 completes the triad of mechanisms.

nodes.name: example outcome comparison of SAEDT, SPEDT and SCDT
nodes.description: Across Newcomb variants and (sequential) toxoplasmosis, SAEDT/SPEDT win in predictor-linked tasks, while SCDT wins in toxoplasmosis; demonstrates no single framework dominates.
nodes.node_rationale: Table 1 and accompanying text serve as empirical validation.

nodes.name: need for new physicalistic decision theory beyond CDT/EDT
nodes.description: Because each extended framework loses in some scenario, a more robust physicalistic decision theory is required for safety-critical agents.
nodes.node_rationale: Section 4 emphasises this open research need.

nodes.name: use of commitment mechanisms to influence predictor expectations
nodes.description: By self-modifying or signing contracts before prediction, an agent can causally affect the predictor, aligning outcomes with higher utility (Newcomb with precommitment).
nodes.node_rationale: Discussed in Example ‘Newcomb with Precommitment’, Section 3.4.

nodes.name: precommitment contract before prediction
nodes.description: A concrete technique where the agent pays a cost to bind itself to pay an even larger penalty if it later two-boxes, thereby shifting predictor’s forecast.

nodes.name: validation of precommitment improving SCDT outcomes
nodes.description: SCDT agent with contract is predicted to one-box and thus gains $1M − $300k, beating default SCDT; demonstrates effectiveness of commitment devices.

nodes.name: information avoidance to prevent sub-optimal evidential updates
nodes.description: Choosing not to observe certain evidence (e.g., contents of opaque box) can keep the agent’s evidential reasoning in a high-utility equilibrium.

nodes.name: policy of not looking into predictor-linked box
nodes.description: Concrete mechanism whereby the agent refuses to open the opaque box before choosing, ensuring evidential link remains favourable.

nodes.name: validation of information avoidance yielding optimal one-boxing
nodes.description: SAEDT/SPEDT agents that avoid looking are predicted to one-box and gain $1M; looking leads to two-boxing with lower payoff, validating strategy.

nodes.name: adopt sequential policy-evidential decision theory for embedded agents
nodes.description: During model-design or fine-tuning, encode decision policies to evaluate actions according to SPEDT value functions, conditioning on entire future policy to better handle predictor correlations.
nodes.intervention_lifecycle_rationale: Proposed at the theoretical design stage (Section 3.3 SPEDT definition).
nodes.intervention_maturity_rationale: Supported only by toy-problem simulations; no large-scale deployment evidence.
nodes.node_rationale: Natural actionable implication of authors’ favourable SPEDT results.

nodes.name: integrate commitment devices into agent policy to steer predictor expectations
nodes.description: Give agents the capability to self-impose penalties or modify their code/policy before prediction points, causally influencing predictors towards cooperative outcomes.
nodes.intervention_lifecycle_rationale: Implemented at design time as part of the decision-making architecture (Section 3.4 precommitment).
nodes.intervention_maturity_rationale: Demonstrated only in toy scenario; practical feasibility untested.
nodes.node_rationale: Directly follows from validation evidence of precommitment benefits.

nodes.name: incorporate information-avoidance policies to preserve advantageous evidential states
nodes.description: Program agents to decline observations that would trigger lower-utility evidential updates when such information is not required for safety or performance.
nodes.intervention_lifecycle_rationale: Set at policy-design stage (Section 3.4 Newcomb with looking).
nodes.intervention_maturity_rationale: Only theoretical demonstration; no empirical large-scale tests.
nodes.node_rationale: Validated in example where avoiding looking secures optimal payoff.
